author: {'steamid': '76561198025187600', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1565325626}
review:
I enjoyed Orphan. The graphic design, music, and sound effects create an excellent atmosphere. The story, albeit simple, was also good enough to keep me intrigued and with just a touch of suspense. I actually appreciated the clean and fun mechanics for saving (a tent) and recovering life (a water canteen or roasting fish). Those didn't have to be there and the mechanics add some class to the game, IMO. The subtle honor paid to Native American culture was a nice touch, too.

The game starts out as stealth-based and, for me at least, moved into combat-based after the first 20% or so of the gameplay. I liked both elements and I wanted to explore everywhere and know what happened next with the story. The game gives you instructions on how to use pretty much everything, without hand-holding. It wasn't hard to figure out at any point.

The caveats: Shooting controls were a little rough to aim for me. A few times, the boy fell through the wall and I had to restart. I think most of the glitches, at least for Apple OS, have been cleaned up at this point.

I backed this game on Kickstarter and I'm quite happy to see this product. I hope you decide to enjoy it, too!

author: {'steamid': '76561198261957551', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 255, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1564244958}
review:
Until the devs either fix the Linux port so it stops trying to illegally read from address 0x24 and segfaulting, or remove Linux from the OS list on the store page, this review will remain negative.

From what I actually played--since I had to install it on Windows to get it to work--there's nothing wrong with the actual game. The UI is clean, the sound design helps the atmosphere, the movement is serviceable, but a bit slow. I'm just hoping the game doesn't pull a Pid, where you have to solve crappy physics puzzles involving frustrating platforming mechanics WHILE dealing with unbearably slow movement and pacing. I haven't played enough to form a solid impression yet, so this review will be updated as I play more. The only reason I posted this super early is because of the Linux issue. That's not okay.

Edit: I don't like the stealth gameplay. I crossed a river and can't get past two drones. I got past several before them, but in the area after the water mill, I hit a brick wall and can't progress. Throwing bottles doesn't seem to do anything to divert attention, and since the play area is 1-dimensional, you can only travel in a line, meaning the cover options are extremely limited, making it a pain in the ass. Usually in a stealth game, or stealth section in a game like Final Fantasy XII or Ocarina of Time, you have 2 or 3 axes to play with, usually north-east-south-west. In this game you only get left-right. You feel me? The stealth gameplay isn't bad (it's not great, either); I just don't like stealth gameplay. It's not a genre I enjoy, and this genre was not conveyed in the genre tags. I'll still recommend it provided the Linux support gets fixed, but I'm getting a refund.

--

If the devs respond telling me that the game is fixed, please provide the following evidence to back it up:

1. the full output of `valgrind ./Orphan` -- just run the game long enough to quit from the menu. As a general rule of thumb, the output should not show anything like "invalid read of size 1", "attempted to read from address 0x24", traceback reports, etc. These are serious bugs and will result in crashes and instability.

2. Some sort of proof that it's running on an actual Linux machine and not a VM/compatibility layer/"test rig". Users don't run your games in test rigs with tons of libraries pre-installed and security features disabled; they run them on real, lived-in operating systems.

review: Admittedly, I haven't spent much time with this yet. However, what I have played has been impressive. Gameplay-wise, the stealth mechanics are pretty good, and I like being able to set my own respawn point pretty much wherever I want (barring near enemies or on non-level surfaces). That said though the controls are a bit strange; wasd is used for movement (obviously), but many of the interaction keys are on the right side of the keyboard. This meant that both my hands were on the keyboard in order to do basic functions, and I assumed that aiming would also be a function of the keyboard and not the mouse. I was wrong about that assumption, and while after discovering this I was curious to see how I was supposed to play the game with its default controls it had crashed shortly afterward. However, this is the end of the negative thing I have about the game. On a visual level it does atmosphere very well, like a more crisp and detailed Limbo, and I love the light effects. Music has so far also been atmospheric, but I know that's something that people have mixed opinions about. Sound design is great; the quality of the sounds in nature, technologically advanced areas, and from enemies is wonderful. Taking this all into consideration then, my experience has been overall positive.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984822255', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 976, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 962, 'last_played': 1541724466}
review:
Disclaimer: I was a backer and translated the game to Brazilian Portuguese, so I have followed all the development.

This game is basicaly a one man endeavor, it is a 2d platformer with GREAT graphics. No, really, this guy must have had a lot of work implementing all the lighting effects that are top notch! Animations, sound and music are good. It is a tad short and some items and mechanics are not fully needed/fleshed out, but it is forgivable, because it is hard to cut things out. The exploration is a little hard, boss fights are nice.

The launch was a little shaky, with some bug that are being squashed daily. I found some, but nothing major. If there is one thing that I have to say that really annoyed me is that it uses frame skipping, and it doesn't work very well. I think this might be a little hard to implement in game maker, but this should be fixed. Even if at 95% of the game my graphics card can run it smoothly at 60fps, some scenes droped to a crawl, and I had to change the config midgame, since auto just seems to lock my gig at 30fps without any need.

So, I highly recommend the game!

PS: did I say the graphics are beautiful? There is even fluid mechanics on the smoke and fog! Very pretty.

review:
*Review in progress*

Backed the project during the kickstarter and forgot about it, was pleasently surprised when i got the key. It might look like a limbo derivative, but plays much differently, It's more of a metroidvania with much focus on exploration and stealth. It looks great for the most part but there are issues with the graphics, especially with the stealth. 

You have a sound and visibility meter like in most stealth games, but you can't really hide in the shadows for the most part,  the game is very obvious where you can hide (behind logs, rocks, reeds) but it doesn't really work as it should sometimes. I have seen areas where you can be seen even if you are perfectly in the middle of a patch of reeds, and the oposite where i was entirely hidden behind a tiny rock that only obsuced half of me. The visibility meter work as it should however so it's not a hughe issue (and most likely due to bugs). There are also similar problems with your water bottle (works like your refillable health kit) sometime you knee deep in water and you can't refill the bottle.

One thing that can be either positive or negative depending on perspective is that it doesn't hold your hand. You pickup items you have no idea how to use, the tutorial is very basic and you quickly find alternate paths to new areas. Don't expect a linear experience is what i'm trying to say. If you are used to the genre you will figure out most pretty quickly. 

I have not finished the game, but will keep updating this review as I go along. I do like the game, it's a lot different than what you might think it is and it's a little rough around the edges and perhaps not the most user friendly game but it's clearly a passion project.

review:
Disclaimer: I backed this on Kickstarter and parts of this review are based on the beta impression.

Orphan is a 2D platformer with a visual style reminiscent of Limbo - but only in that it is played mostly in silhouette. The setting is very different, ranging from gentle rolling hills to dark caves to industrial complexes.

The story is a well written mystery that drives the boy to explore the game's world, and the game is nicely varied with intense boss-fights and challenging puzzles. There is a lot of combat, but it never got too challenging. I mainly played using a gamepad but keyboard and mouse are also supported.

I love the art style and the sound design in this game, it's obvious a lot of effort went into making it the best possible experience.

Most of my experience with the game is with the beta, at this point (patch 1.0.0.5) the game is fully completed and the last remaining bugs are being worked out. It is fully completable and should give you a few fun hours of play.

Still playing and still enjoying, gotten stuck a couple of times.

[h1] In A Nutshell [/h1]

ğŸ”µ [b] Pros [/b]
+ Great art style and atmosphere.
+ Good audio quality for an indie.
+ interesting, evocative story filled with mystery.
+ Successful mix of shooter, platform and story-driven game.
+ Involving and challenging multi-phase bosses.
+ Several secret equipment pieces to find.
+ Above average duration and content for the genre.

ğŸ”´ [b] Cons [/b]
- Noticeable quantity of bugs and glitches in several situations.
- Some quality of life problems regarding orientation, healing mechanics and design.

When opening up Orphan, I thought: "yeah okay another Limbo clone" - but my mind changed quickly. Orphan definitely is a game with its own identity, despite there being a lot of these "side scrolling narrative games" around. The first thing to impress me was the narration, which is excellently realized considering this is a one-man project, conveying strong situations and emotions at the right times.

Don't expect this to be a game where you just walk around listening to a story: Orphan is a well blended mix of equal parts shooter, platformer and storytelling game, featuring stealth sections at first, and after that, has pretty frequent combat against a variety of enemies. Throughout the adventure, by defeating reasonably tough bosses, you will be able to acquire different alien weapons to face the invasion, while careful exploration will lead to secret, often ancient pieces of equipment giving additional armor and abilities. Other than shooting enemies and running around dangerous places, you will also have to solve some, admittedly quite simple, environmental puzzles, featuring mostly item recovering to activate or deactivate something.

The bad side of all this is about bugs and quality of life, as the rest is excellent: several kinds and degrees of bugs are present despite updates, but almost none of them is critical, just annoying. Quality of life needs aswell an improvement regarding orientation, as you could possibly end up without any clue about where to go or where you are, while the ability to decide whether or not to use your hard-earned food to heal while camping should be added.

Overall Orphan left me with a positive impression, and is yet another testament to the fact devs do not need AAA budgets and resources to produce quality games.

[h1] In-depth Feature Analysis [/h1]


ğŸ® [b] Gameplay [/b]
The gameplay of Orphan is divided in Exploration and Combat for the most part.

The world is divided into zones, each featuring respawning enemies (when present), and linked always to at least another area. Interaction with the environment is limited, as mostly only progression essential elements are interactive, and little else. Several areas feature environmental hazards such as pitfalls, electricity, or poisonous gas. A map of the world is not available, and this can make exploration difficult especially when you have to backtrack in order to arrive in other areas and progress the story. Getting lost is common. The presence of secret areas containing actually useful items like armor or gadgets, is surely an incentive to explore every corner. 

The game also features near-mandatory stealth sections, mostly in the first part. In addition, collecting fish from lakes in a fishing mini-game is possible and they will be used to restore Hp when camping. Hp can also be restored by drinking water.


ğŸ“– [b] Story [/b]
The story of Orphan is minimalist narration wise, featuring only a handful dialogues and cut-scenes, and mostly uses indirect narration describing what happens just with events. Still, it's one of the game's strongest features, and manages to convey strong moments in an excellent way. It carries with a good pace until the end and is overall interesting. Solid.


ğŸ‘Š [b] Combat System [/b]
Combat uses a system similar to most side-scrolling games: your character is able to use throwing weapons like grenades, distractions as bottles, and a bit later high-tech guns with different functions. Each gun at your disposal has a protective shield working differently for each one, and an attack mode, that often removes the shield. other than this, rolling is also a mechanic and reduces damage even if hit. Armor is aswell a statistic and can be improved temporary or permanently with certain items, reducing damage significantly.

Boss fights are challenging and not to be taken lightly even with several secret items collected. Generally enemies hit hard, fast, and will kill the unprepared. Combat in orphan has overall a good feel and is more than enough for this type of game.


ğŸ’° [b] Content & Pricing [/b]
Priced at 12,50â‚¬ base tag, and offering around 6-9 hours of content if you explore everything and take your time: for the delivered quality (and quantity) the game is definitely worth full price.


ğŸ”— [b] Balance & Challenge [/b]
Overall balance is good and there are not major issues, existing one have been fixed. Challenge is above average for the genre with a couple boss fights resulting a real challenge. There is no difficulty selection. 


[h1] Technical Analysis [/h1]


ğŸ¥ [b] Graphics [/b]
Orphan features a pleasant graphical style, minimalist in some ways but also rich with modern effects and details. Particular care has been taken in realizing environments, cut-scenes, and models. Overall a quality work that contributes greatly in creating immersion.

ğŸ”Š [b] Sound [/b]
Directional, good quality sound effects and environmental sounds. A solid mark in this field.

ğŸ”© [b] Performance & Stability [/b]
No issues about performance [i7 4820K, GTX1080, 16GB RAM at 4K], however some crashes occurred a few times.

ğŸ’» [b] Artificial Intelligence [/b]
Enemies have a decent AI reacting to sounds and patrolling areas with suspicious activity, bosses have a multi-phase pattern where they change behavior based on HP. Overall a good job in this field. The only issue being that in stealth sections some enemies notice you from seemingly impossible distances or angles.

ğŸ  [b] Quality of Life [/b]
Quick selection of items is missing, a button to switch between items without opening the backpack each time would be nice. A better map to not get lost when forced to backtrack aswell would improve the experience significantly. Too far placement of HP sources (water) from bosses can be annoying, as it forces backtrack to regen HP.

ğŸ› [b] Bugs & Issues [/b]
There are quite a few issues and bugs around levels, of various natures and severity. Most critical ones have been ironed out, but do not expect, for now, a perfectly polished experience. 


[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
Orphan is a surprisingly good one-man project indie game, scoring good marks in almost all fields, and delivering what is needed to make this kind of game great. If you enjoy sci-fi settings, some challenge, and a good story, this is the game for you.
